text: miami horror illumination
all right my needle drops it's time that
was douchey it's time to do an album
review uh miami horror illumination
miami horror is an electro project from
australia and was started by a mr
benjamin plant and what caught me about
this lp is just its really interesting
mix of influences there are some aspects
to it that would make it fit right in on
the dance floor maybe even appeal to
these guys but it doesn't really use a
lot of the harsh sounds the buzzing bass
and just the hard-hitting beats that a
lot of house music uses if you're on the
lookout for another cross this is not it
so you've got all of these house and
electro sounds throughout this lp but
also there's quite a bit of disco
influence on here too people like abba
totally have an imprint on this album
some bee gees flavored falsetto vocals
you got bump and bass and a lot of drum
beats that emphasize the hi-hat a lot of
subtlety and there was some decent song
songwriting going on here too it's not
just one lyric repeating over one beat
and just kind of going on into oblivion
because people aren't really paying
attention they're either drinking
dancing or screwing considering that and
all of the nicer sounds this thing
doesn't feel too out of place either on
a set of headphones and it's quite
possibly one of the finest mixes of
electro and disco i've ever come across
because miami horror works in the 4 4
beats the fluttering electronic blips
and bloops and the flange building up
right before to when the beat kicks in
it's kind of hard to tell where all the
disco stuff starts and all the electro
stuff ends it's kind of seamlessly
pulled together it's like sped up cfcf
it's like crystal castles but more radio
friendly it's like chill wave but with
less nostalgia and speaking of chill
wave alan palomo of neon indian actually
guests on one of the tracks here
holidays however you slice or compare
this lp it all adds up to some really
essential dance tracks for 2010. i guess
if we're going to come down on some
major gripes for a dance record it's
kind of varied but in general this is
not really a varied album almost every
track just ends up in a similar dance
beat but miami har works to at least
introduce all of these tracks
differently so that you get at least a
little bit of a sensation of a
difference between all of the tracks
whether it be the acoustic opener on
moon theory or the narrated female
vocals on echoplex it does get a little
cheesy here and there and it's not the
most bold statement in dance music it's
not anything that labels like ed banger
or dfa records haven't brought us before
and they could have done a lot more to
change things up but i think that would
have taken away to how much of a dance
record this really is here and there the
sounds on this lp do get a little
generic but it's very nice to hear dance
music of this style not just in all
these loosely placed mp3s uploaded and
downloaded throughout the blogosphere
but instead on this one
easy to listen to album this is a really
popular sound in electro right now and i
think what miami horror has done is put
together an album of songs that are very
definitive when it comes to this style
i'm kind of feeling a strong six to a
light seven on this thing it's okay it's
good as a whole but i'm most likely
gonna gravitate just toward that neon
indian collaboration and the singles
which isn't necessarily a bad thing
but what do you guys think of this thing
do you love it do you hate it and why
anthony fantano
miami horror illumination
forever
you
